name: Abó
description: The Abó Visitor Center includes a bookstore and restrooms. There is a short trail through the 17th century Mission of San Gregorio de Abó, and another short trail around the Spanish resettlement structures. During the summer (May 1-October 31), the visitor center, trails and restrooms at Abó are open daily 9:00am-5:00pm. During the winter (November 1-April 30), the Abó Visitor Center is open Thursday-Monday 9:00am-4:00pm. Trails and restrooms are open daily from 9:00am-4:00pm.
audioDescription: When you drive up NM 513 for 0.75 miles, you will notice a gravel turn-around that passes a building; the road continues but goes to private residences. The parking is in a gravel lot just before the turn-around on the right side of the road in front of the 19th century resettlement structures. When you get out of the car, the visitor center will be to your left up a small incline accessed via a red asphalt trail. The small visitor center features a bookstore, several interpretive panels and a model of how the church may once have looked. To access the restrooms, continue past the visitor center and turn right on the paved trail shortly before crossing the road.
passportStampLocationDescription: Each of our three sites and Headquarters have a stamp that will say Salinas Pueblo Missions NM, the date, and the name of the site. The Abó Visitor Center has the Abó stamp.

passportStampImages.title: Abó Cancellation Stamp

directionsInfo: Located 9 miles west of Mountainair, off Highway 60. Access road on black-top NM Highway 513, ¾ mile from highway. RV turnaround.

operatingHours.description:
During the winter season (Nov 1 through April 30), the Abó Visitor Center is open Thursday-Monday from 9:00 a.m. - 4:00 p.m. The park grounds are open daily from 9:00 a.m. - 4:00 p.m.

The visitor center is closed Thanksgiving Day, Christmas Day, and New Year's Day.

name: Acadian Cultural Center
description: Permanent and special exhibits, an award-winning film, ranger talks, and programs share the history, customs, language, and contemporary culture of the Acadians who became Louisiana's Cajuns. Admission to the center and to most programs is free.
audioDescription: The visitor center at the Acadian Cultural Center has three main components: a museum, a theater, and a book store. The approach to the building itself is a wide brick walkway with a slight incline. It turns to the right as you near the building; here there are three flag poles displaying, from left to right, the Louisiana state flag, the United States flag and the flag of Acadiana. On either side are green plants, trees and grasses. In season, there are lavender azaleas. As you enter through the front door, you are in a large, high-ceilinged room with several square pillars spaced throughout. From that position, there are the following points of interest: Ten feet ahead is the information desk, staffed by a park ranger. To the right, 25 feet away is the counter for the book store. The book store has tables and shelves with a variety of products including books and toys. To your left, roughly 60 feet away, is the museum. The museum exhibits are related to Cajun culture, displaying clothing, musical instruments, among other items. At the 1:00 position is the entrance to the theater, 30 feet away. The theater has 175 seats with a movie screen at the front of the room. At roughly the 10:00 position, you’ll find the bathroom vestibule, 45 feet away. There is one, single-occupancy bathroom available to visitors; once you enter the vestibule, turn left and walk along a wall to your left to the bathroom door ahead. (You will pass a closest door on your left before reaching the bathroom.) As you navigate your surroundings, keep in mind that there are pillars spaced at regular intervals around the space.

name: Adams National Historical Park Visitor Center
description: From May 1 through October 30, 2022, the Adams National Historical Park Visitor Center will be open Wednesday through Sunday from 9:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m. Pending availability, tickets for the guided tours can be purchased at the Visitor Center. All America the Beautiful passes are available for purchase at the Visitor Center. The Eastern National Gift Shop is located here. Please drive to 44 Saville Ave in Quincy for free, validated parking.
audioDescription: The Adams National Historical Park Visitor Center is located in The Galleria at President's Place. This is a multi-level, brick building. The Visitor Center is on the first floor with a row of floor to ceiling windows. It can be accessed by car or public transportation. To access by car park in the parking garage located at 44 Saville Ave., Quincy, MA. Take the elevator to the first floor. Follow the hallway. Take your first right past the elevators. The Visitor Center will be the last door on your left prior to exiting the building. To access by Public Transportation take the Red Line of the Subway (called the "T") to Quincy Center. Exit Quincy Center to the left. Walk out of the parking lot and cross the street at the crosswalk. The Visitor Center will be to your left on that road.

name: Agate Fossil Beds National Monument Visitor Center
description: The visitor center is open every day except Thanksgiving, Christmas, and New Years Day. Summer hours are May 15 through September 30. The visitor center features a large diorama of Miocene mammal fossils, 12-minute park movie, and the James H. Cook Collection of Lakota artifacts, a unique collection of American Indian artifacts gifted to the Cook family by Chief Red Cloud and his descendants. Two trails are open every day from dawn till dusk.
audioDescription: Three handicap accessible parking spaces are on the front right of the parking lot. Concrete sidewalk goes to the right, 300 feet to a two story dark brown building with double glass doors. The doors open to a tiled foyer area. Accessible restrooms are to the right, with men's room door to the left along the wall, a locked storage door in the middle and women's room to the right. Continue straight from the doors through another set of double doors 15 feet further. The floor surface changes from tile to carpet as you enter a large room about 60 feet wide and 40 feet deep. Ranger information desk is straight ahead at the far wall. Artifact display cases are spaced throughout the floor plan. On the right is a glass door to the James H Cook Collection of Lakota Artifacts. On the left is a large diorama display of seven large skeletons of fossilized mammals behind a 3 foot high railing. A theater with a closed captioned but not-audio described park movie is through a door against the left front wall.
directionsInfo: From US 20: 22 miles south of Harrison, NE on State Hwy 29, then three miles east on River Road (paved) From US 26: 34 miles north of Mitchell, NE on State Hwy 29, then three miles east on River Road (paved). From State Hwy 71: 25 miles west on the unpaved portion of River Road.

operatingHours.description:

The park's two trails are open from dawn till dusk every day.

name: Albright Visitor Center
description: Here you can gather park information, orient yourself to the rest of the park (including road conditions, and campground and lodge availability), shop for souvenirs, explore exhibits to learn more about the wildlife and history of Yellowstone, join a ranger program, acquire a permit for fishing or backcountry camping at the backcountry office in the basement, or use the restrooms. This visitor center also has free Wi-Fi.
audioDescription: Albright Visitor Center (286 words) A cement sidewalk leads to the visitor center, located in a 2-story, T-shaped building with a basement and second floor, made of light brown, grey, and beige, rough-cut large blocks of stone. The gabled roof is made of reddish-orange, half-round shaped clay tiles. The building has 4 chimneys and 3 dormer windows. The first and second levels have tall windows with 12 panes of glass; a triangular area surrounding one half-circle window at center on the second level. The basement’s wide, horizontal windows, are covered by vertical wrought iron bars. The second story has eleven windows across the front of the building. In the front of the building are three, 4-foot wide cement stairs with wrought iron railings on both left and right that lead to a porch that spans the entire front of the building. The center set of steps leads directly to the visitor center entrance under signage that reads “Horace M. Albright Visitor Center.” On the far right is an accessible ramp. The stairs and accessible ramp lead to a porch on the first level with 3 sets of double doors: on the left, a staff entrance; in the middle, the visitor center entrance; on the right, doors marked “not an entrance.” Two ash-colored wooden benches flank the center doors. The porch is shaded by a roof supported by stone pillars; the double-door entrance to the visitor center is just 6 feet forward. In the back, on the left side of the building, a ramp and set of stairs lead to the backcountry permit office. The visitor center is shaded by a large spruce and two cottonwood trees at left and right. Inside features include an information desk staffed by park rangers, exhibits, and restrooms. END OF MESSAGE
passportStampLocationDescription: The "Mammoth Visitor Center" passport stamp is located within the Yellowstone Forever Park Store part of the Albright Visitor Center.

directionsInfo: The Albright Visitor Center is located at Mammoth Hot Springs, five miles south of the North Entrance at the northern part of the upper loop of the Grand Loop Road. It is housed in one of the old stone buildings of Fort Yellowstone, a US Army fort built during the early days of the national park.

operatingHours.description: Albright Visitor Center is located in the northern part of the park near the Mammoth Hot Springs terraces. Park information can be found on bulletin boards posted at the visitor center, as well as by using the NPS Yellowstone app. Visitor center opening date subject to change. Check locally if in the park. Check back frequently for updates. When available, rangers are available outside to answer questions.

name: Aleutian World War II National Historic Area Visitor Center
description: The visitor center for Aleutian World War II National Historic Area is in the town of Unalaska. It is owned and operated by the Ounalashka Company and is located in the historic Naval Aerology building. The center interprets both the military events of the Campaign and the relocation and overwhelming hardships faced by the Alaska Native residents of the Aleutian and Pribilof Islands. Inside there are exhibits, a reconstructed 1940s radio room, and a 1940s style theater showing World War II-era films.
passportStampLocationDescription: The passport stamp is located in the Aerology Building.
directionsInfo: The Aleutian World War II Visitor Center is located at the Unalaska Airport, within walking distance of both the cruise ship dock and the Grand Aleutian Hotel.

operatingHours.description: In the summer, the visitor center is open 8 am to 5 pm Monday through Friday.  Additional hours may be available when a cruise ship or ferry is in Unalaska.

name: Alibates Visitor Center
description: The Alibates Visitor Center is home to exhibits, a theater and outdoor gardens, showcasing the history of Alibates Flint and the cultures that used this precious natural resource throughout the last 13,000 years. It is also the meeting place for ranger-led hikes and tours of the monument, demonstrations, and numerous special events throughout the year. Open Mon-Fri 9 a.m. to 4:00 p.m. 7 days a week . Limited wireless or cellular access is available.

name: American Camp Visitor Center
description: The American Camp visitor center is located on Cattle Point Road on the island's southern peninsula. It is currently closed until the Spring of 2023, but the grounds of American Camp remain open 24 hours per day, all year. This visitor center opened to the public in June of 2022 and features incredible new exhibits detailing the Coast Salish presence, military history of San Juan Island, and our island's ecology.

Wandering among the exhibits, visitors get a mini-tour of Alaska. One can also learn about recreating on public lands in the state as well as materials for educators to bring back to their classrooms. Staffed by National Park Rangers, the center offers a plethora of information.

name: Andrew Johnson NHS Visitor Center
description: Begin your visit to the Andrew Johnson National Historic Site at the Visitor Center. Here you will receive orientation to the other parts of the park, in addition to general information, brochures, and directions. The Visitor Center houses the site's 13 1/2 minute film "Defender of the Constitution," the Presidential museum, Andrew Johnson's original Tailor Shop, and the Eastern National bookstore.
audioDescription: The Andrew Johnson NHS parking lot has twelve spaces. One is designated as the handicapped spot. Two are reserved for buses and/or RVs. The lot is tight, however, and many people with motor homes choose to park in the on-street spaces, which have a two hour limit. From the parking lot, the visitor will cross the Andrew Johnson Early Home yard. A brick sidewalk runs through the yard, and they may stop and read waysides or walk through the open first floor of the home, which contains exhibits pertaining to Johnson's early life. When the visitor reaches College Street, they will find a crosswalk with a sign advising on-coming traffic to stop for pedestrians, as it is mid-street and not at the designated corner cross-walk. Visitors may choose to cross at either location, but ensure that traffic has come to a stop before proceeding at both. The restrooms and water fountains will be on your right as you walk toward the main Visitor Center entrance. The double doors into the Visitor Center are manually automatic. A ranger or volunteer will be on hand to provide orientation to the park as soon as you enter the room.
passportStampLocationDescription: Andrew Johnson NHS has several passport stamps available at the Visitor Center. There is one stamp for the overall park, another for the National Cemetery, and one that contains an image of the Tailor Shop. There is an additional stamp created by the Historical Commission for an independent book, but visitors love to add it as well!

passportStampImages.title: Passport Stamp station

emailAddresses.description: This is the general park email account for information. The request will be forwarded to the appropriate recipient based on topic.

directionsInfo: GPS The GPS setting for Andrew Johnson NHS may be listed as 121 Monument Avenue, which is the park HQ building in the National Cemetery. Use 101 North College Street, Greeneville, TN for the visitor Center. Plane The closest airport is the Tri-Cities Regional Airport, 43 miles NE of Greeneville. From the airport, take I-81 South to exit 36 and follow the signs to Greeneville. Car From I-81S take exit 36 to Rt. 172 south to Greeneville. From I-81N take exit 23 to Rt. 11E north to Greeneville.

operatingHours.description: At the Visitor Center park staff or volunteers will provide an overview of the site. Here you can view the orientation film, "Andrew Johnson: Defender of the Constitution," see original artifacts, and vote for Andrew Johnson's acquittal or guilt at the impeachment display. In the historic Memorial Building you can gain a sense of place as you stand before Andrew Johnson's enclosed Tailor Shop.
operatingHours.name: Andrew Johnson NHS Visitor Center

name: Antietam National Battlefield Visitor Center
description: This spring, Antietam National Battlefield will begin a $6.8 million project to rehabilitate and preserve the historic visitor center, which originally opened to the public in the winter of 1963. We expect to close the visitor center summer of 2021 and reopen it in late 2022. During the construction the park will install a temporary visitor center building. Currently the lobby, bookstore and restrooms are open.

name: Apgar Visitor Center
description: Apgar Visitor Center is located 2 miles east of the West Glacier entrance to the park. Rangers are on duty to assist with trip planning. The visitor center is the hub for the Going-to-the-Sun Road shuttle system on the west side of the park.
audioDescription: Apgar Visitor Center is adjacent to a long paved parking lot and surrounded by a dense lodge pole pine forest. Past a flagpole a walkway leads in front of the visitor center, next to a series of exhibits. The building itself has large wooden columns and big glass windows and doors in front. Inside there are two service desks a few exhibits and a small book store.
passportStampLocationDescription: Passport Stamps are available in several locations including: Apgar Visitor Center, Logan Pass Visitor Center, St. Mary Visitor Center, Many Glacier Ranger Station, Two Medicine Ranger Station, Polebridge Ranger Station, Park Headquarters, and the train depot in West Glacier, MT.

directionsInfo: Enter the park from Hwy 2 at West Glacier and proceed through the entrance station 2 miles to the visitor center.

operatingHours.description: The Apgar Visitor Center is open seven days a week during normal business hours in the summer. In the winters the Apgar Visitor Center is sometimes open on weekends.

name: Apollo Beach Visitor Center
description: Canaveral National Seashore's Visitor Center is located at 7611 S. Atlantic Ave, New Smyrna Beach, FL 32169. Pick up a brochure or a Junior Ranger book. Get information about where to visit in the park. For more information call (386) 428 - 3384 extension 0.
audioDescription: Canaveral National Seashore's Visitor Center is a single story with one main entrance. The restrooms are located on the same side as the parking lot. Behind the visitor center is a pavilion and a dock for your enjoyment. The American flag is flying out front. A small garden of native plants such as coontie and beach dune sunflowers grow here. There are benches out front under the awning to rest in the shade.
passportStampLocationDescription: This is the Canaveral National Seashore virtual visit stamp. Visit the Apollo Beach Visitor Center for our Apollo Beach stamp. Visit Playalinda Beach and ask the ranger at the entrance for the Playalinda Beach stamp. For more information on directions call the visitor center at (386) 428-3384 ext. 0.

name: Appomattox Court House Visitor Center
description: The visitor center is located inside the reconstructed Appomattox Courthouse. It offers restroom facilities, visitor information and guidance, a 17-minute film, and exhibits focused on the history of Appomattox Court House. Guided talks and living history programs begin in the visitor center.
audioDescription: A red brick two story, reconstructed historic courthouse building, with steps leading to a porch and doors to enter the second floor placed prominently in the center of the structure as you approach. A brick path leads around the stairs to the entry door on the main first floor. There are four windows placed evenly, two on each level, with dark green shutters on each. The visitor center is ringed by a wooden board fence.
directionsInfo: Appomattox Court House National Historical Park is located in south central Virginia approximately 95 miles west of Richmond. The main visitor parking area is located on VA Rt. 24, 2 miles (4.8 km) northeast of the town of Appomattox, VA. The closest airport is in Lynchburg, VA, 25 miles (40.3 km) west.

operatingHours.description: The Appomattox Court House Visitor Center operates daily from 9-5. Inside, park staff can make visit recommendations and provide maps and informational brochures. Restrooms, exhibits, and the park's 17-minute orientation film are available in the visitor center.
operatingHours.name: Appomattox Court House Visitor Center

images.caption: Start your visit to Appomattox Court House National Historical Park at the reconstructed courthouse visitor center.

name: Arches Visitor Center
description: The visitor center is generally open every day except December 25. Hours vary by season. You can learn about the park from exhibits and a bookstore. (NOTE: The park film theater is temporarily closed.) Rangers are on duty to answer your questions. Restrooms and drinking water are available.
audioDescription: Arches National Park Visitor center is located just beyond the park entrance off of highway 191 North of Moab, UT. The building and parking lot sit at the base of towering sandstone walls formed by the Moab fault. Beyond the turn into the parking lot, the park road snakes up and above the visitor center, which leads to the rest of the park atop the plateau. Once past the entrance booths, a right turn after the roundabout leads to the parking lot and visitor center. The parking lot is spacious, with a small shade structure and picnic tables on its Northwest side. The visitor center building is located to the right-- northeast of the lot. The building itself is multi-storied and angular, painted different shades of beige, tan, and light maroon. In front of the building is an extensive interpretive plaza, shaded by two columns of ramada style roofing, one running along the Northwest side of the plaza, the other, along the Southeast. Each section is held up by several sandstone brick pillars. In the center of these two shaded sections sits a series of decorative boulders and bronze statues of wildlife. Restrooms and other amenities are located just beyond these statues along the northeast wall. The overall low profile of the building and shade structures gives the sense that the structure is part of the colorful sandstone layers located beyond and above it. Scanning the Interpretive plaza clockwise from the parking lot, several trash and recycling bins are visible near the leftmost brick pillar. The following pillar features two water filling stations, a spicket and informational panel on each side. The next pillar, which extends back towards the visitor center entrance in the northeast corner of the plaza, features a large NPS Arrowhead and the words ‘Arches National Park.’ The remaining two pillars curve towards the building entrance and feature large informational panels about wildlife and park features respectively. A section of windows with two double doors on the left marks the entrance to the visitor center building. Continuing to the right, the northeast wall of the plaza features a low bench, payphones, trashcan, and a shaded alcove with access to two gendered and one handicapped accessible family restroom. Opposite the first column of pillars, a second shade structure runs East to south. Underneath the structure, the pillars feature additional informational panels; “Climbing and Canyoneering,” “What to do at Arches,” “Park Features,” and a gold lettered quote that reads: “Extraordinary arches, awe-inspiring landscapes.” Closer to the parking lot, the last two pillars also feature low benches. A flagpole with a raised American Flag stands closest to the road on the sidewalk before the parking lot. In the center of the plaza are several large rocks and life-sized bronze statues of wildlife in Arches. The floor beneath these statues is characterized by a sweeping patch of rough, light gray cement, in contrast to the smooth orange cement of the rest of the plaza. A male bighorn sheep sits atop the largest rock, a small lizard and two ravens perch on a neighboring boulders. A female bighorn sheep and baby stand closest to the parking lot, another lizard on a smaller rock behind them. Past these statues, one enters to visitor center through the double doors in the northernmost corner of the visitor center plaza. The entryway leads to a large mural of delicate arch, flanked by two digital trip planning kiosks. Directly in front of this mural is a large three dimensional relief map of the park at about waist height. To the left of this map is the park store. Several kiosks and display shelves are present in the entry way of the store. To the right of the relief map is the visitor center information desk. Behind the desk are panels with photographs of different prominent rock features in the park. To the right, a small inlet against the large windows facing the plaza holds two televisions mounted to each wall, used for orientation and safety videos. To the left of the information desk is the exhibit hall, which leads to various exhibits on the geology, environment, wildlife, and history of the park. The exhibit hall features a large two story window that looks up towards the sandstone wall behind the visitor center, and several large scale models of arches and sandstone features weave throughout the exhibits. On the far end of the exhibit hall sits the entryway to the theater, which seats 114 persons for showings of the park film.
passportStampLocationDescription: Three passport stamps are available at Arches Visitor Center: 1) the standard cancellation stamp with the park name and date, 2) a version with an image of Delicate Arch, 3) the standard cancellation stamp for Old Spanish Trail with the trail name and date. 2016 NPS centennial stamp available upon request.

name: Ash River Visitor Center
description: The Ash River Visitor Center is open during our summer season from late May to late September. Ash River Visitor Center will be closed annually over the winter season. The Ash River Visitor Center is located in the historic Meadwood Lodge pictured above. Take a moment to explore this historic, rustic building. Watch your head, as some interior doorways were constructed for shorter individuals.
audioDescription: The Ash River Visitor center is a historic wooden cabin. Concrete stairs lead up to the cabin from the parking lot and an accessible path leads to the visitor center from the left side of the visitor parking. A separate building for restrooms is located to the right of the visitor center with a slight path separating the two.

name: Assateague Island Visitor Center
description: The Assateague Island Visitor Center is located in the Maryland District of Assateague Island before the Verrazzano Bridge entrance into the park. As of June 12, 2021 the Assateague Island Visitor Center is open daily from 9 am - 4 pm.
audioDescription: The Assateague Island Visitor Center is located in the Maryland District of Assateague Island on the southern side of Route 611, before the Verrazzano Bridge entrance into the park. The GPS address is 11800 Marsh View Lane, Berlin, Maryland 21811. Parking for vehicles, RVs and trailers is available on the north and northwest side of the building. The Assateague Island Visitor Center faces northwest and is a rectangular, one story gray building with white trim. A decorative flying bird sculpture is attached to the north side of the building. A slightly curved ramp gradually leads up to a covered deck. The covered deck connects the visitor center on its east side, to the restroom facilities on its west side. Under the covered deck is a large table map display of Assateague Island. Attached to the southside of the restroom facilities is a large outdoor bench that looks out over the Sinepuxent Bay. Rocking chairs and a binocular viewing station provide views to the south and east over the bay. The visitor center has a set of glass automated doors that may be used by pushing the button on the south side of the doors. Inside the visitor center there is a book store immediately on the north side of the building. As the building continues east there is an information desk, an auditorium and a touch tank exhibit on the north side wall. Along the east side of the building are two large aquariums and a horse skeleton exhibit. The south side of the visitor center has a large anchor on display, panels explaining island movement and windows looking out over the marsh. In the center of the building there are more exhibits and panels.

name: Bainbridge Island Japanese American Exclusion Memorial
description: The Bainbridge Island Japanese American Exclusion Memorial is an outdoor exhibit commemorating the internment of Japanese Americans from Bainbridge Island in the state of Washington. Wayside markers provide history and other information. This site is a unit of the Minidoka National Historic Site in Idaho. The park is located at Pritchard Park, 3.8 miles from the Winslow Ferry Terminal. Its open year-round during daylight hours. The memorial is staffed by a Park Ranger during the summer months.

directionsInfo: Via public transit The Memorial is accessible via Kitsap Transit bus #99. This bus runs from the Bainbridge Island ferry terminal. Get off at the Eagle Harbor at New Sweden stop and head east on Eagle Harbor Drive towards New Sweden Road. More information can be found via the Washington State Department of Transit and Kitsap Transit.

name: Bandy Creek Visitor Center
description: Exhibits Focus on the recreational opportunities found within Big South Fork and throughout the seven surrounding counties. Facilities & Activities Ask a ranger what to do in the park. free public WiFi, bookstore; park permits; restrooms; vending machines, and ice sales.
audioDescription: From the parking lot to the visitor center is a step up onto a sidewalk and then a right turn up onto a porch which has access to the restrooms. The men's room is the first door on the left and the women's room is the next door on the left. Continuing straight ahead will take you to the front door of the visitor center which opens outward towards the porch. Once inside the door there is an information desk directly ahead about 5 feet. A ranger is usually at this desk for assistance. The interior of the visitor center is an open room with a fireplace at the center in the back. There is a bookstore entrance on the left side of the fireplace. Just left of the fireplace is another entrance/exit that steps out onto the sidewalk. Just outside these doors is the accessible restroom or family restroom on the left.
passportStampLocationDescription: The passport stamp may be found inside the bookstore which is located directly left from the main front door entrance of the visitor center and straight back through the main room. The stamp will be on a table to the left of the center of the bookstore room.

name: Barataria Preserve
description: With more than 26,000 acres of wild Louisiana wetlands, the Barataria Preserve's hardwood forest, swamp, bayous, and marsh offer trails, picnic areas, fishing, hunting (in season and with permits), and wildlife viewing. Visitor center films and exhibits explain the wetlands habitat and current environmental challenges; ranger programs are offered daily. Programs at the environmental education center are available by reservation. Admission to the preserve and to most programs is free.
audioDescription: The visitor center is accessed from the parking lot by a wooden ramp. The ramp begins at the sidewalk and is slightly inclined. The first section of the ramp is about 30 ft., then turns right about 40 degrees. The next section is about 35 ft., then turns right again about 30 degrees. This section is 40 ft. to the wooden deck in front of the visitor center. The deck is level. The visitor center is 40 ft. ahead. Entry is through glass doors into a small foyer then about 6 ft. to a second set of glass doors. The ranger's desk is directly ahead about 8 ft. To the right is a museum, with exhibits of the geology, biology, natural history, and human history of the Barataria region. The museum has a wide entrance and is about 20 ft. from the ranger's desk. The exhibits are along the walls and in a large island in the middle of the museum holding more exhibits. A few of the exhibits are equipped with sound; most are not. Also in the visitor center is a theater. Entry to the theater is through a door that is immediately to the right of the entrance. The theater is entered by making a right U-turn after entering the visitor center. The restrooms are outside the visitor center in a separate building. Leave the visitor center through the glass doors and turn sharply right. The building with the restrooms is about 40 ft. away. The men's room is the nearest on the left side of the building, and the women's restroom is on the right. In between are a large drinking fountain and entrance to a handicapped/family restroom. Also between the visitor center and the building with the restrooms are two picnic tables, both closer to the visitor center than to the restroom.

directionsInfo: The Barataria Preserve is located 17 miles south of New Orleans on the west bank of the Mississippi River; Barataria Blvd./Highway 45 runs through the preserve. name: Bear Valley Visitor Center
description: The park's primary visitor center provides an orientation of the park's roads, trails, and human and natural history. The interior exhibit space provides a glimpse of the diverse ecosystems and cultural heritage of the park. Audio-visual programs, shown in the auditorium, are available upon request. Natural history books, cards, and posters are for sale in the bookstore. Beach fire permits may be obtained here.
audioDescription: The Bear Valley Visitor Center is located in a fairly flat meadow at the base of a wooded ridge that rises to the west. Some of the western part of the meadow serves as a fenced horse pasture. The Bear Valley Visitor Center was constructed to resemble a large barn and is painted gray. Inside the visitor center are a bookstore, an information desk, an auditorium, and museum exhibits. On the right just before one passes through the visitor center's front double doors is a hallway leading to the restrooms. As one enters the visitor center, the bookstore is immediately to one's left, the information desk ahead and to the left, the entrance to the auditorium immediately beyond the information desk, and the museum exhibits to the right. The museum exhibits contain taxidermied animals and exhibits about the park's major ecosystems, including coastal wetlands, coastal shorelines, coastal grasslands, forests, and open ocean. There are also exhibits about human history at Point Reyes.

emailAddresses.description:

name: Beaufort Visitor Information Center
description: Available Facilities: Information, maps, restrooms & first aid, Programs and Amenities: Exhibits on island ecology and history, park map, park passport stamp. Free Jr Ranger and Jr Ranger Adventures activity guides.
audioDescription: The Beaufort Visitor Information Center is located on Front Street in the old Beaufort Post Office building which was originally built in 1942. The main door swings out for entry and is reached by steps from the sidewalk. Just inside the main door you are in a long lobby with the Visitor Information Center to the right and public restrooms located to the left. A wheel chair accessible ramp and push button door opener (door swings out) allow entry to the building lobby from the off-street parking area on the right side of the building. There is a handicap parking area right beside this ramp. Public restrooms are located just off the lobby on the left of the main door -- to reach, turn left, walk to the end of the lobby, turn right and walk about 10 steps where you will pass through an open archway. Turn left, and step forward -- the men's restroom is straight ahead, and the women's is on the left. Handicap stalls and diaper changing locations are available in both facilities. The visitor information center is to the right of the main door -- walk to the end of the lobby, turn left and walk forward past the handicap accessible door and through a single wide door into the visitor information center. This is a single room with touchable exhibits and an information desk. This center is often a self-service facility, but if the ranger or volunteer is there you can ask for a recorded self-guided tour of the various exhibits inside the building.

This visitor center is one of two Ferry Gateways to the Cape Lookout Light Station and Shackleford Banks.

name: Ben Reifel Visitor Center
description: Located at park headquarters, the Ben Reifel Visitor Center features exhibits, an air conditioned theater,and restroom facilities.
audioDescription: Ben Reifel Visitor Center. 331 words. The one-story, tan, wood and steel visitor center has grey concrete set of parallel to a gently sloping concrete path, lead to the main entrance of the building. The building is surrounded on its west and south side by large parking lots accommodating dozens of vehicles. The building is bordered on its north and west by horizontally layered, jagged, badlands formations extending between 50 and 100 feet high. On the north side of the building, there are three picnic chairs with shade structures above them. Across the parking lot on the Visitor Center's eastern wall, there is a tan concrete welcome sign with the National Park Service logo and the text "Welcome to the Ben Reifel Visitor Center." The main entrance is on the west side of the building, with a secondary entrance on the south side. On the southwest corner of the building, the text "Ben Reifel Visitor Center" is written in metal letters and affixed to the building. The main entrance leads to a lobby-area accommodating at most twelve people at a time. On one side is a curved information desk with a large map showing the locations of visitor services and animals within the park. On the other side is the park bookstore with a variety of souvenir and educational items for sale. At the northeast corner of the room there is a darkly light pathway that leads to exhibits about the park's resources. Beside that is the entrance to the theater. The southeast corner of the lobby leads to a hallway with three doors, in succession from north to south, they are the men's restroom, the women's restroom, and the entrance to the fossil preparation laboratory where visitors can observe and interact with paleontology technicians as they prepare fossils throughout the park. There is a hallway to the east that is marked for employees only, and to the south a pair of double doors leading outside the building. End of Description.

name: Bent's Old Fort
description: Visitors park at the parking lot and walk the 1/4 mile (1,275 feet) trail to the fort where you will be met by an interpreter wearing period clothing. Brochures and a documentary film are available in one of the fort rooms. Western National Parks bookstore is located at the left rear corner of the fort.
audioDescription: Today, Bent’s Old Fort National Historic Site features a reconstructed version of the 1840s adobe trading post. Archeological excavations and original sketches, paintings, and diaries were used to replicate the features of the fort, which was reconstructed during the country’s bicentennial and Colorado’s centennial in 1976. The reconstructed fort is a dominant feature on the short grass prairie. It is at a strategic location on the northern bank of the Arkansas River. The reconstructed fort has two stories accessed by stairways. Modern restrooms are available at the visitor center parking lot area and in the fort.
passportStampLocationDescription: The passport station is located outside the Western National Parks Association bookstore in the rear of the fort. There is a passport stamp for Bent's Old Fort National Historic Site and the Santa Fe National Historic Trail. The passport station is at 38.04027778 N latitude, 103.42944444 W longitude.

directionsInfo: The park is accessed via U.S. Highway 50 and Highway 194. From La Junta, Colorado on U.S. Highway 50, take Highway 109 north 1 mile to Highway 194, then east on Highway 194 six miles to the fort. From Las Animas, Colorado, on U.S. Highway 50, take Highway 194 west 13 miles. Set your GPS to 35110 State Highway 194 E., La Junta, CO.

operatingHours.description: Bent's Old Fort Visitor Center is open 7 days a week, except on Thanksgiving, Christmas and New Year's Day. Summer hours (end of May through early September) for the fort are 8:00 am to 5:30 pm. The gate is open during summer hours from 7:00 am to 5:30 pm. Winter hours (early September 8 through late May) for the fort are 9:00 am to 4:00 pm. The gate is open during winter hours from 7:00 am to 4:00 pm.

name: Bering Land Bridge Visitor Center
description: Nome, AK is not on the road system and may be reached by commercial flights. From Nome, AK you may visit Bering Land Bridge visitor center which is about 1 mile away from the Nome airport. Keep in mind that Nome, AK is 100 miles (160 km) from the preserve's boundaries. You may reach the preserve by chartering a bush plane, by foot, boat or snowmobile.
audioDescription: The Bering Land Bridge Visitor Center is located inside the Sitnasuak Building on Front Street in Nome, AK. The Visitor Center entrance is flanked by two large exhibit panels. On the left, is a floor-to-ceiling photograph depicting a verdant landscape of rolling hills. Giant tors jut out of the ground. On the right, a welcome panel depicts Beringia, the lost continent, with an overview of the area's geologic past. Upon entering the Visitor Center, you will find several display cases containing replicas of Ice Age animal skulls and corresponding informative panels. In the center of the room, is a large display case containing a woolly mammoth leg bone and a piece of tusk. On the wall furthest from the door, is a touch screen monitor offering a variety of interpretive media, including interactive maps, 3D fossils, and a variety of Story Maps about the region. The other half of the room is comprised of a small Alaska Geographic bookstore and information desk. At the information desk you will find examples of rocks from the preserve, brochures, and maps.

name: Big Oak Flat Information Station
description: The Big Oak Flat Information Station has an information desk, wilderness permit desk, and Yosemite Conservancy Bookstore. In the winter, self-registration wilderness permits for the Crane Flat area and Tioga Road trailheads only, are available on the front porch. You must bring your own bear canister when the information station is closed. Wilderness permits are required for overnight stays in Yosemite's Wilderness. Designated accessible parking spaces are available in front of the facility.
audioDescription: The Big Oak Flat Information Station building is a one-story, long, modular trailer. An accessible ramp ascends across the length of the front of the building onto a deck. A brown metal sign at the top of the ramp reads Big Oak Flat Information Station and has a National Park Service logo. It goes on to read: visitor information, with an icon of a question mark, wilderness permits, with an icon of a person hiking, and bookstore, with an icon of an open book. On the deck, near the side entrance to the information station are two large, grey, metal bins that look like trash bins. Similar signs on both bins read: No trash, bear canister rental return, with an illustration of a bears' head. Next to the information station are restrooms and vending machines, with similar architectural features.

description: Start your trip here! Get free maps and information, meet a park ranger, and learn about the Big Thicket's plants, animals, and history. Staying awhile? Watch a short film in the theater, browse the bookstore, and enjoy a picnic in the covered picnic area.
audioDescription: The visitor center is built like a large log cabin in the woods. Outside the visitor center is a looping parking area with a picnic area in the middle. Inside the visitor center is a front desk where you can talk with a park ranger and a gift shop for souvenirs. There's a large theater room where the park film is shown. Inside the exhibit hall, various displays explain the diversity of plant and animal life found in the Big Thicket. Restrooms and a drinking fountain can be found on the outside of the visitor center.

name: Black Rock Nature Center
description: Located in the heart of beautiful Black Rock Campground. Bookstore, water, flush toilets, picnic area.
audioDescription: The Black Rock Nature Center is nestled in the heart of the Black Rock Campground, surrounded to the east, south, and west by the Little San Bernardino Mountains with dense forests of Joshua trees all around. The main campground road leads south from the entrance to a small parking area in front of a single-story rectangular building with a low peaked roof. The building is painted pale yellow and the roof has bright red shingles. There is a set of 6 stairs with a center handrail that lead up to the building’s entrance. The building may also be accessed without stairs by using a sidewalk on the west side. The entrance to the building is a single swinging door that opens out. The entrance door leads to a hallway. On the right side of the hallway is a counter where rangers greet visitors and provide information. On the left is a closed door that leads to a conference room and a large map mounted to the wall showing trails in the area. After the counter on the right is the entrance to a small gift shop that sells books and souvenirs. After the entrance to the gift shop on the right is a display window with information about the current exhibit. Past the display window and also on the right is a water fountain and bottle fill station. Across from the display window, on the left side of the entry way is a bench with 2 seats separated by a low table and another closed door that leads to the conference room. The entry way has an exit door opposite the entrance door which opens out to a sandy staff parking area. Passing straight through the gift shop is a small gallery. The walls and ceiling are made of wooden planks, art is displayed on white exhibit boards. There is a low bench with three seats in the center of the room. The gallery changes three times a year to feature work from the park’s artists in residence and local students. Continuing straight through the gallery along the right-hand wall is a low ramp with a handrail on the left side. Up the ramp and to the left is a hallway with two single occupancy bathrooms on the left side of the hallway.
passportStampLocationDescription: The Black Rock Nature Center has a dated stamp specific to Black Rock Nature Center as well as a picture stamp of a Joshua tree.

name: Blue Heron Interpretive Center
description: Exhibits The Blue Heron Mining Community can be visited at any time to view historic structures and listen to audio programs. Facilities & Activities Ask a ranger what to do in the park; free public WiFi, bookstore; park permits; restrooms; vending machines, and concession stand. Railroad Ride The Big South Fork Scenic Railway travels from the Stearns Depot to the Blue Heron Mining Community in a 45-minute trip. The train remains approximately an hour at Blue Heron before returning to Stearns.
audioDescription: The visitor information desk is located inside a small room just off the depot platform. The long platform may be accessed by a long straight ramp with a concrete wall. Once upon the platform, the visitor information center is a few yards straight and then turn to the right to access the room. The information desk is straight in front of the entrance door with a cash register. Just to the left of the doorway is a small bookstore with books and souvenirs for sale. The restrooms are outside the entrance door and right. There are toilet stalls and sinks in each restroom.
passportStampLocationDescription: The passport stamp is available right next to the cash register at the front desk of the visitor contact station. Ask for assistance if needed.

name: Blue Ridge Music Center
description: The Blue Ridge Music Center celebrates the music and musicians of the Blue Ridge. Established by the U.S. Congress in 1997, with support from The National Council for the Traditional Arts, the Music Center includes an outdoor amphitheater, an indoor theater, and exhibits highlighting the historical significance of the region’s music.
passportStampLocationDescription: The passport stamps are located in the America's National Parks store in the visitor center.

directionsInfo: The Blue Ridge Parkway Music Center is located at Milepost 213 on the Virginia/North Carolina state border.

operatingHours.description: The Blue Ridge Music Center is open daily from 10:00 AM - 5:00 PM daily. Enjoy mid-day music in the breezeway from noon - 4:00 PM.

name: Blue Ridge Parkway Visitor Center
description: The visitor center features exhibits that showcase the natural and cultural history of the area, as well as the recreational opportunities offered by the region. Open year-round, the visitor center features Parkway information, an America's National Parks store, and a Blue Ridge National Heritage Area information desk.
passportStampLocationDescription: The passport stamps are located in the America's National Parks store in the visitor center.

directionsInfo: From I-40, exit at #53 and follow the signs, heading east on US 74A toward Lake Lure and turn right on the Parkway on-ramp. Make a right to head north on the Parkway and turn left up the driveway for the visitor center in less than a mile. If you entered the Parkway from US-25/Hendersonville Rd or NC-191/Brevard Rd, continue north for 10-15 minutes, and turn when you see the visitor center sign. From US-70/Tunnel Rd, drive south about 5 minutes, and turn when you see the visitor center sign.

operatingHours.description: Open year-round, except Thanksgiving, Christmas, and New Year's Day. Subject to temporary closures during periods of inclement weather.
operatingHours.name: Blue Ridge Parkway Visitor Center

name: Bodie Island Visitor Center
description: Approximately six miles south of the seashore's northern entrance is the Bodie Island Visitor Center. This visitor center is located in the historic Bodie Island Lighthouse Double Keepers' Quarters at the end of a short park road off of NC Highway 12 across from Coquina Beach. The visitor center is a great place to get oriented and browse the park store. Outside the visitor center, a path leads to the 156-foot Bodie Island Lighthouse, which is open for tours seasonally.
audioDescription: In front of the Bodie Island Lighthouse and Light Keepers’ Quarters are two parking lots. Both the north and south lots have a curved sidewalk leading to the front porch of the keeper’s quarters which serves as the Bodie Island Visitor Center. The park store is located inside the visitor center in the room to the right. Restrooms are located outside the visitor center in a separate, small building which is located along the marsh boardwalk
directionsInfo: The Bodie Island Visitor Center is located at the northern end of the park along NC-12 and just south of the town of Nags Head on the Outer Banks of North Carolina.

name: Booker T. Washington National Monument Visitor Center
description: The visitor center is open daily from 9:00 a.m. - 5:00 p.m., except for Thanksgiving, December 25, and January 1. Please call the park phone at 540-721-2094 to find out if the park is open or closed during inclement weather.
audioDescription: The visitor center contains the America's National Parks bookstore, an interactive exhibit room, and the "Measure of a Man" 14 minute video. Visitors can obtain a brochure from a park ranger or volunteer at the visitor center desk as you enter the visitor center. The person at the desk can then start the video or orient you to the park grounds.

passportStampImages.altText: The passport stamp for Booker T. Washington National Monument
passportStampImages.title: Passport Stamp

directionsInfo: The monument is located on VA 122 (Booker T. Washington Highway), 22 miles southeast of Roanoke, VA. From I-81 take I-581, then US 220 south from Roanoke to VA 122. From the Blue Ridge Parkway take VA 43 south to VA 122. From Lynchburg take US 460 west to VA 122.

operatingHours.description: Contact the park at 540/721-2094 when there is inclement weather to find out about closures.
operatingHours.name: Booker T. Washington National Monument Visitor Center
